etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in James Nicol (1810–1879), geologist. From French roméite, apparently alteration (with suffix substitution: compare -ite) of roméine

definitions: An antimony-containing mineral which occurs as yellow to reddish-brown octahedral crystals, typically in metamorphosed manganese-bearing hydrothermal deposits.

notes.text: Roméite is an antimonate of calcium (usually containing small amounts of iron, titanium, manganese, and other elements), Ca₂Sb₂O₇. Crystal system: cubic.
